member.name: T:Kvasir.Core.DataConverter
member.summary: A utility for converting objects of one type into objects of another type, and possibly vice-versa.

remarks.para: A represents a possibly reversible function that maps instance of one CLR type into instances of another. This mapping can be relatively simple (i.e. formatting a string to be ALL CAPS) or relatively complex (establishing a database connection from an user-defined structure). This allows flexibility in the definition of the conversion mechanism without burdening the user on the potential complexities that underlie that logic. The client is presented with a simple conversion interface with which they can perform transformations.

A , at a minimum, must support conversion of every instance of some "source type" into instances of some "result type." This forward conversion can only fail when the source instance is malformed or in some other invalid state: conversion of a valid source instance can never result in an exception. Optionally, DataConverts can provide for converting back from instances of the "result" type into instances of the "source" type; this is known as a "bidirectional" converter, and the specifics of the reversal mechanism (e.g. what happens when two or more source instances map to the same result instance, which is then reversed) are defined by the underlying conversion mechanic. Clients should thus be careful when using the API, as Revert(Convert(X)) is not required to yield X.

Both the conversion and reversion APIs operate in type-erased contexts. will throw a runtime exception if an input object does not match the expected type; the class further guarantees that the returned value, though type-erased, can be safely cast.

member.summary: Converts an instance of back into an instance of .
member.remarks: Because the underlying conversion mechanism need not be bijective (that is, multiple different source objects can convert into the same result object), the API does not necessarily present a true inversion. For a given result object R, the only guarantees are that repeated calls to the API will yield the same source object and that Convert(Revert(R)) == R.
member.param: The result object.
member.returns: The reversion of into an instance of .
member.exception: if this is not bidirectional.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.BasicField
member.summary: A Field whose data type has no intrinsic constraints beyond those imposed by the back-end storage.

remarks.para: The value of a Field can be restricted either intrinsically or extrinsically. An intrinsic restriction is one imposed by the data type and nullability of the Field; this restriction is imposed by the actual storage mechanism in the back-end provider. Intrinsic restrictions are common to all Fields of a particular data type, e.g. the maximum range of allowable integer values for a Field of type is the same regardless of what Table the Field belongs to. Extrinsic restrictions, conversely, are those that are further imposed on a Field-by-Field basis and can therefore differ inter- and intra-Table. While most intrinsic constraints are abstracted behind the class, most extrinsic restrictions must be manually imposed by a on the Table to which the Field belongs. However, some extrinsic restrictions are modeled directly by the Schema Layer of Kvasir.
The class models a Field that does not have any such extrinsic restrictions.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.DBType
member.summary: The semantic data type for a Field.

remarks.para: The is strictly a semantic specification, incorporating nothing about the actual mechanism by which the type is represented in a back-end database. Different RDBMS providers realize semantic types differently; for exaple, SQL Server does not distinguish between signed and unsigned integers whereas MySQL does. is intended to partition the data type space along these universal semantic fault lines, leaving the actual storage mechanics up to the back-end provider being used.

Because of this abstract angle, certain aspects of a data type are not represented directly by the class. This includes precisions for floating point types, ranges for all numeric and date-like types, encodings for text types, and others. This extends to enumeration types, where the discrete set of allowed values is specified at the Field level rather than by the . This overall abstraction allows for a single Schema translation to be used for any back-end RDBMS.
The various semantic type categories are represented as distinct instances exposed as psudo-enumerators: it is not possible to create custom instances.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.DBValue
member.summary: A thin, type-controlled wrapper around a CLR object that can be stored in a back-end relational database.

remarks.para: The struct is intended to provide an abstraction over the generalized CLR for use in contexts where compile-time type informaton is not available. The advantage in using a over raw a is that the former is guaranteed to only ever hold an object that can actually be stored in a back-end RDBMS, whereas the latter could feasibly hold anything. Additionally, a never actually wraps a value directly: a sentinel is used such that accessing the raw value is always valid.

The strong typing afforded by a CLR enum is lost when the enumerator values are stored in a back-end relational database. Some providers afford value checking, either through an explicit enum data typ or via CHECK constraints; however, even in these cases, the actual storage is generally either an integer or a string. For this reason, a cannot wrap a CLR enumerator: is the client's responsibility to convert the CLR enumerator into the corresponding database object, be it an integer or another supported type.

The same general logic applies to conversions from other CLR types, including between CLR types that are otherwise supported by Kvasir. The struct is intended to wrap exactly the value that is to be stored in the database, with the burden of performing any transforms falling on the client.

Because a might hold the NULL sentinel value, which is valid for any data type, it is not strictly possible to determine the of a particular . To check if a particular instance can be safely used for a Field of a particular , use the dedicated API.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.EnumField
member.summary: A Field whose data type has an intrinsic constraint limiting the allowed values to a discrete set of strings.

remarks.para: The value of a Field can be restricted either intrinsically or extrinsically. An intrinsic restriction is one imposed by the data type and nullability of the Field; this restriction is imposed by the actual storage mechanism in the back-end provider. Intrinsic restrictions are common to all Fields of a particular data type, e.g. the maximum range of allowable integer values for a Field of type is the same regardless of what Table the Field belongs to. Extrinsic restrictions, conversely, are those that are further imposed on a Field-by-Field basis and can therefore differ inter- and intra-Table. While most intrinsic constraints are abstracted behind the class, most extrinsic restrictions must be manually imposed by a on the Table to which the Field belongs. However, some extrinsic restrictions are modeled directly by the Schema Layer of Kvasir.

The class models a Field to which is applied an extrinsic enueration restriction. Such a Field is necessarily treated as a string by users, but the allowed values are discrete rather than infinite. Some back-end RDBMS providers (such as MySQL) actually offer an optimized storage mechanism for such Fields, where the data is stored as an integer but read and written as a string. Similar restrictions on non-text data types require a with a condition based around an .

member.param: The name of the new .

The default value of the new .
The restricted enumerator values of the new .
member.pre: The arguments provided to the constructor must, collectively, define a valid Field. In addition to requiring that all arguments be non-, this means that the default value, if present, is compatible with the Field's data type. Furthermore, that compatible default value can only be if the of the Field is . Finally, there must be at least one allowed value, and all such values must be something other than while maintaining compatability with the data type.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.IField
member.summary: The interface for a single Field in a Table of a relational database.

remarks.para: Fields in a relational database are analogous to columns in the two-dimensional matrix that is a Table. Each Field has, at a minimum, a name, data type, and nullability; collectively, this metadata controls how the Field is referenced by other Tables and SQL statements/expressions and what values are allowed for the Field. Additionally, a Field can have a default value that is used when the Field is omitted from an INSERT statement.

The representation of Fields at the Schema Layer of Kvasir is an abstraction over the actual realization of the Field in a back-end RDBMS. Specifically, the data type of a Field is specified in a storage-agnostic manner that makes no guarantees as to the actual back-end storage mechanisms. For example, the data type of a Field does not manage the precision of floating-point values or the master domain of integers. These aspects of the data type can differ from provider to provider; the abstract representation of the Field therefore allows a single Schema translation to be used for any back-end RDBMS provider.

This interface is closed: it can only be implemented by types in the Kvasir assembly. It is guaranteed that at least on type in the Kvasir assembly implements this interface, though the upper bound is unspecified. External assemblies can reference, use, and extend the interface to add cursory functionality and enrich their own APIs if desired.

member.name: P:Kvasir.Schema.IField.Name
member.summary: The name of this Field.

member.name: P:Kvasir.Schema.IField.DataType
member.summary: The data type of this Field.

member.name: P:Kvasir.Schema.IField.Nullability
member.summary: The nullability of this Field.
member.remarks: Nullability refers to whether or not the value of a Field can be NULL. This status restricts several facets of a Schema, such as the default value that a Field can take on and the reactionary behaviors of a Foreign Key that includes the Field. The nullability of a Field does not depend on the Field's data type.

member.summary: The default value of this Field.
member.remarks: A Field is not required to have a default value, and the default value may be if the Field is nullable. A SOME instance indicates the presene of a default value, with that value being wrapped by the . Conversely, a NONE instance indicates the absence of a default value.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.IKey
member.summary: The interface for a single internal Key on a Table of a relational database.

remarks.para: In a relational database, a Key is a non-empty, possibly proper subset of a Table's Fields that are required to form a unique tuple for each row in that Table. Keys often reflect real-world domain identity relations, such as social security numbers, client usernames, or any of various IDs. Key uniqueness is imposed by the database provider, rejecting INSERT and UPDATE statements that would create multiple rows with the same tuple of values.

This interface is closed: it can only be implemented by types in the Kvasir assembly. It is guaranteed that at least on type in the Kvasir assembly implements this interface, though the upper bound is unspecified. External assemblies can reference, use, and extend the interface to add cursory functionality and enrich their own APIs if desired.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.ITable
member.summary: The interface for a single Table in a relational database.

remarks.para: A Table is the primary unit of organization in a relational database. Each Table can be thought of as a two-dimensional matrix of data, where the columns are Fields and the rows are data entries. A Table is principally defined by its name and the collection of constitutent Fields; additionally, every Table must have exactly one Primary Key - a tuple of Fields that must be unique for all member rows. Tables can also have Candidate Keys, which are tuples that could be a Primary Key but just aren't.

The structure of a Table can also impose restrictions on the values of its Fields, on top of the implicit and/or explicit restrictions imposed by the data type of the Fields themselves. The first form of constraint is the Foreign Key constraint, which requires that the values of a tuple of Fields match the values of a Primary Key for some data entry row in another Table; this constraint imposes referential integrity. The second form of constraint is the CHECK constraint, which allows the specification of arbitrary conditional logic on the values of the Fields in a row of data. A Table can have any number of either type of constraint, including none at all.

This interface is closed: it can only be implemented by types in the Kvasir assembly. It is guaranteed that at least on type in the Kvasir assembly implements this interface, though the upper bound is unspecified. External assemblies can reference, use, and extend the interface to add cursory functionality and enrich their own APIs if desired.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete
member.summary: An enumeration representing the various ON DELETE behaviors that can be applied to a Foreign Key.
member.remarks: Foreign Keys are intended to enforce data integrity across multiple Tables, ensuring that a value (or tuple of values) in one Table references a row in another. DELETE operations can therefore disrupt the validity of Foreign Keys, as the row(s) being deleted can feasibly be one referenced by a Foreign Key in another Table. When this happens, the behavior is controlled by the ON DELETE behavior of the Foreign Key that referenes the to-be-deleted row(s). If multiple Foreign Keys reference the targeted row(s) with different ON DELETE behavior, the result depends on the back-end RDBMS provider being used.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.Prevent
member.summary: Prevent the deletion of a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key. This behavior requires that the referencing data be modified or removed prior to removal of the referenced data. This is the strictest behavior.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.Cascade
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is deleted, also delete the referencing row(s). This behavior turns a single DELETE statement targeting a single Table into a collection of DELETE statements targeting multiple Tables, as the referencing row(s) being deleted can themselves be referenced rows in another Foreign Key.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.SetNull
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is deleted, set the values of any referencing Fields to NULL. For obvious reasons, this behavior can only be applied to a Foreign Key where all the constituent Fields are nullable.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.SetDefault
member.summary: When a rwo that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is deleted, set the valus of any referencing Fields to their default value. For obvious reasons, this behavior can only be applied to a Foreign Key where all the constituent Fields have explicitly specified defalut values.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnDelete.NoAction
member.summary: Take no action when a row being deleted is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key. This behavior can lead to data integrity issues, as the referencing row no longer refers to an extant target. This is the weakest behavior. Some back-end RDBMS providers will raise errors or exceptions when such data integrity violations arse.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate
member.summary: An enumeration representing the various ON UPDATE behaviors that can be applied to a Foreign Key.
member.remarks: Foreign Keys are intended to enforce data integrity across multiple Tables, ensuring that a value (or tuple of values) in one Table references a row in another. UPDATE operations can therefore disrupt the validity of Foreign Keys, as the row(s) being updated can feasibly be one referenced by a Foreign Key in another Table. When this happens, the behavior is controlled by the ON UPDATE behavior of the Foreign Key that referenes the to-be-updated row(s). If multiple Foreign Keys reference the targeted row(s) with different ON UPDATE behavior, the result depends on the back-end RDBMS provider being used.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.Prevent
member.summary: Prevent the updating of a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key. This behavior effectively disables updating referenced data unless the referencing data is first deleted or updated itself to refer to a different, still-valid target.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.Cascade
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is updated, also update the referencing row(s). This behavior turns a single UPDATE statement targeting a single Table into a collection of UPDATE statements targeting multiple Tables, as the referencing row(s) being updated can themselves be referenced rows in another Foreign Key.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.SetNull
member.summary: When a row that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is updated, set the values of any referencing Fields to NULL. For obvious reasons, this behavior can only be applied to a Foreign Key where all the constituent Fields are nullable.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.SetDefault
member.summary: When a rwo that is referenced by a row in another Table via a Foreign Key is updated, set the valus of any referencing Fields to their default value. For obvious reasons, this behavior can only be applied to a Foreign Key where all the constituent Fields have explicitly specified defalut values.

member.name: F:Kvasir.Schema.OnUpdate.NoAction

member.summary: A single Table in a back-end relational database.
member.remarks: At present, there is only one implementation of the interface in Kvasir. The class is used to represent entity Tables, list Tables, and relation Tables.

The Foreign Keys of the new .
The CHECK constraints applied to the new .
member.pre: The arguments provided to the constructor must, collectively, define a valid Table. In addition to requiring that all arguments be non-, this means that there are at least two Fields that all lateral Field references (i.e. from the Primary Key, all Candidate Keys, all Foreign Keys, and all CHECK constraints are to Fields that are present in the Table. Additionally, all Fields must have a unique name.

member.name: T:Kvasir.Transcription.IBuilderFactory
member.summary: The interface for a factory that creates syntactically consistent declaration builders for generating CREATE TABLE statements.

remarks.para: The interface is an abstract way to represent the syntax rules of a particular back-end RDBMS provider. Implementations of the interface and the builders therefrom created are passed to the various components of the Schema Layer to generate CREATE TABLE statements once the schema structures have been synthesized. In this way, a single used to interface with any back-end RDBMS provider.

Examples of syntax rules that can vary from provider to provider may include, but are not limited to:
Escaping the names of Fields, Tables, and Constraints
Specific data types
Realization of enumeration-type Fields
Spelling of logical comparison operators
